newsitem.title: UK: LCE cocoa ends just above lows, ranges stay tight - SEPT 11.
newsitem.headline: LCE cocoa ends just above lows, ranges stay tight - SEPT 11.

text.p: Cocoa futures remained trapped in tight ranges on Wednesday as light origin selling kept values away from the highs, traders said.
"We've been moving in a five pound range -- it's been thin for three days now. We just can't sustain the higher values at the moment," said one.

"Every day there's a bit of origin in the market but the volumes are such the market takes a bit of a hit because there's nothing supporting it," he said, adding that a weak New York performance was not helping sentiment in London.
At the close the benchmark December contract stood six stg lower at 970 stg after moving between 969 and 975 stg.
Other traded positions were weaker in a light volume of 1,658 lots.
Switch activity was also limited with May/September attracting the most activity, market sources said.
Traders said there was also some market confusion over the various forecasts for the world 1996/97 cocoa deficit.
"The market does not know how to react...There are many forecasts for 1996/97 floating about," another trader said.

The International Cocoa Organization (ICCO) on Monday forecast a world deficit of 225,000 tonnes, followed promptly on Tuesday by UK research house Landell Mills (LMC) forecasting a deficit of 150,000 tonnes.
Both were hot on the heels of U.S. trade house Cargill pegging the 1996/97 deficit at 178,000 tonnes last week.
The market is also awaiting a world 1996/97 balance later this week from British trade house E D & F Man.
But technical analysts said there was still room for world cocoa prices to move to the upside.
"The long term trend in cocoa remains broadly directionless and there are no signs of that changing yet," said Elli Gifford in Investment Research's latest monthly technical summary.

"...the fact that the 52-week moving average is rising still hints that the market argument has taken on a bullish bias, suggesting that attempts to clear resistance at the recent highs could, in due course, resume."
